climbs.name: Too High to Fly
climbs.fa: Matt Schutz, Jeremey Ross, Graham Doe (Dec 2011)

content.description: Slab aficionados take note. Start on a highly technical slab. Move through the low crux on micro edges, mini crimps and purely friction. After you have made it through the first 4 bolts, take a breath and relax as  the difficulty eases above.
content.location: 2nd bolted route from the right. To the left of Hot White Dike.

content.description: A delicate slab climb ends at a roof where a vertical knob studded climb resumes. An excellent route, definitely the most diverse climb on the wall.
content.location:
Starts off the pointy block. Thin friction leads past two bolts (crux is getting to the roof). Once at the roof, place a cam and move right and up over the roof (use a long runner) and ascend the spectacular face between two closely spaced water grooves (runnels). 3 bolts protect this upper section, and 2' slings are ideal for additional pro.

Note:  The FA was well underway when a vicious thundershower ensued and placing additional bolts was out of the question on the sprint to the top. So the 3 upper bolts were added on the second ascent when it was safe to do so.

climbs.name: Hot White Dike
climbs.fa: Graham Doe, Jeremey Ross and Matt Schutz (Dec 2011)

content.description: A tricky start leads to easier climbing above. Techy footwork on a thin white dike is the key no nailing the onsight. Excellent slab route.
content.location: Rightish side of the wall, first obvious bolted line, and to the left (~50 feet) of a giant tree

content.description: Start near the middle of the wall and traverse up and left across the low angle bulge that slants diagonally left. Stop when you reach a black dish. A thin technical slab climb ensues as you reach the dish and rise above it to easier climbing. Probably harder if it had lead bolts. FA party gives permission to bolt.
content.protection: Currently la Top Rope (reach anchors by climbing another route).
content.location: Start near the middle of the wall and traverse up and left across the low angle bulge that slants diagonally left. Stop when you reach a black dish.

climbs.name: Going Coastal
climbs.fa: Tom Slater, Jeremy Ross, Monica Gomez 9-2011

content.description: On the far right side of the Corduroy Wall. Start by a huge block. Wander up the slab with huge knobs to a steeper headwall above that has huge plates. This then yields to lower angle slab to bolted anchors located way off to the left (recycled anchors, perhaps a rap station?). Walk off climber's right. A loooong and fun romp for beginner climbers who can't do the technical slab climbs to the left. Anchors located lower down and more above this route would improve this route greatly.
content.location: On the far right side of the Corduroy Wall. Start by ascending a huge block and then onto the main wall (or any variation that gets you onto the main wall).  This may be the hardest part of the climb.
